message_1: What is the half-life of radioactive isotope uranium-238, given that its decay constant is 1.54 x 10^-10 s^-1?
message_2:
The half-life of a radioactive isotope can be calculated using the following formula:

Half-life (T) = ln(2) / decay constant (λ)

Given the decay constant (λ) of uranium-238 is 1.54 x 10^-10 s^-1, we can calculate its half-life as follows:

T = ln(2) / (1.54 x 10^-10 s^-1)

T ≈ 0.693 / (1.54 x 10^-10 s^-1)

T ≈ 4.50 x 10^9 s

To convert seconds to years, divide by the number of seconds in a year (approximately 3.1536 x 10^7 s/year):

T ≈ 4.50 x 10^9 s / (3.1536 x 10^7 s/year)

T ≈ 142.7 million years

So, the half-life of uranium-238 is approximately 142.7 million years.
